isis.stitle: International® DT 466E, DT 466, 530, 530E, and HT 530 Diesel Engines - Rocker Arm Assembly, Camshaft Assembly, Tappets, and Push Rods - Clean, Inspect, Measure, and Test - Valve Lever and Rocker Arm Assembly

svcproc.title: Valve Lever and Rocker Arm Assembly

svcsubproc.title: Clean Valve Lever and Rocker Arm Assembly

step1.para: Immerse all components in suitable solvent.
Use filtered compressed air to dry components.
Inspect rocker shaft for scoring, pitting, or wear steps. Replace rocker shaft if any of these visual signs of wear are present.

caution.para: To prevent possible engine damage, replace rocker shaft with like rocker shaft. If replacing with new style rocker shaft all valve train components must be replaced. Replacement of old style valve train components requires complete replacement of all valve train components, including push rod assemblies, roller tappet assemblies, and rocker arm assemblies.

note.para: It is normal to see a slight polishing at lever contact area.

step1.para: Measure rocker shaft in a non-contact area. Use an Outside Micrometer . This dimension will be used as a baseline shaft diameter.
Measure each lever contact areas vertically.

figure.caption: Measure contact and non-contact areas vertically

step1.para: Subtract each twelve vertical measurements from baseline diameter. If difference is greater than 0.025 mm (0.001 in), replace rocker shaft.
Verify oil supply holes are open. Clean holes with small wire or other suitable tool if necessary.

caution.para: To avoid possible engine failure, if replacing rocker shaft, all twelve valve levers must be replaced. Reusing rocker arms on a new shaft will not allow for an adequate break-in period and will cause premature failure of shaft and levers.

To prevent possible engine damage, do not install new style valve train components in engines produced with old style valve train components. Replacement of old style valve train components requires complete replacement of all valve train components, including push rod assemblies, roller tappet assemblies, and rocker arm assemblies.

note.para: New valve levers may be installed on a used shaft.

Cup plugs at each end of shaft are replaceable. Do not disturb cup plugs unless damaged, leaking hard part failure or contaminated oil. If replacement is required, pry damaged cup plug out and press in new cup plug.

step1.para: Inspect cup plugs on each end of shaft for evidence of damage.
If cup plug(s) is damaged pry the damaged cup plug out.
Clean the area around the cup plug.
Press in a new cup plug in the end of the shaft.
Inspect rocker shaft for scoring, pitting, or signs of excessive wear. If valve lever bore is visibly damaged, replace valve lever.

Inspect lower half of valve lever. Most significant wear will occur at this location. Valve levers may be reused in their original locations if phosphate coating is worn off and the shaft is not replaced.

note.para: Purpose of black phosphate coating on valve lever is to provide a break-in lubricant between rocker shaft and valve lever bore. It is normal to see black phosphate coatings worn off of bottom of lever arm in the shaft and bore contact area. Valve levers must be labeled and installed in their original locations to maintain proper wear pattern.

step1.para: Measure valve lever bore diameter at two locations with Telescoping Gauge and Outside Micrometer . Measure diameter at A-B and C-D . If difference between diameters is greater than or equal to 0.025 mm (0.001 in), replace valve lever.
Inspect valve stem contact button on valve lever for scoring, pitting, or signs of excessive wear. Replace valve lever if button is worn.

caution.para: To prevent possible engine damage, do not install new style valve train components in engines produced with old style valve train components. Replacement of old style valve train components requires complete replacement of all valve train components, including push rod assemblies, roller tappet assemblies, and rocker arm assemblies.

step1.para: Inspect valve lash adjuster for signs of wear. Replace adjuster screw if excessive wear is found.
Inspect top oil feed hole in valve lever. Clean hole with small wire or other suitable tool if necessary.
Inspect shaft springs for rust, pitting, and cracks. Replace as required.

Measure shaft spring tension with Valve and Clutch Spring Tester (ZTSE2241)
. Measure free length (no load applied). Apply correct test load and measure test length.
Replace any shaft springs that do not meet " Specifications ."
